intro: Camelina caucasica, commonly known as Caucasian mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the Caucasus region. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lanceolate leaves and yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are small, oval, and contain high levels of oil, making them valuable for biodiesel production. Camelina caucasica is also noted for its ability to thrive in poor soils and its potential as a hardy oilseed crop.
